bibl.title: Extracts of letters from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James E. Peabody, September 22 and October 1, 1928

div1.p: Kean comments on photos to be used by Peabody in his article and supplies Moran's address. He has a high opinion of Moran.

div1.head: Extracts of letters from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James E. Peabody, September 22 and October 1, 1928
div1.p:
E X T R A C T S
From letters of General Jefferson R. Kean, U. S. Army, Retired
to
Prof. James E. Peabody, The Morris High School,
New York City.
oo0oo
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D. C.
22 September, 1928. My dear Prof. Peabody:

Your letter has just come with the galley of the illustrations
of your article. That Figure 14 is certainly no joke on me, because I
have not and never had the remotest connection with it. People who like
practical jokes might think it a joke on Gorgas because it certainly is
a most unflattering picture of him, but it is he all right. I will look
up a picture as soon as I go home and sent it to you. I will try to find
you one of those days when I was a Major. As you have three pictures of
Kissinger and one of Jernegan, why don't you have a picture of Moran who
was the real hero of that bunch, the man who volunteered at the same
time as Kissinger, who always refused to accept any gratuity and has
always shown a fine spirit of dignity and independence. I think we can
probably scrape up a picture of him if you want it. His present address
is John J. Moran, Empedrado 22, Havana, Cuba.
o o o o o o o o o o o o o o o o o o o

With best wishes, I am,
Very sincerely yours,
J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U. S. Army, Retired.

ooOoo
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D. C.
October 1, 1928. My dear Professor Peabody:

I am sending you by separate enclosure a photographic reproduct-
ion of the contract between Major Reed and Antonio Benino and two photo-
graphs of Camp Lazear, and also a photograph of me taken when in Cuba. I
have not been able to put my hands on a photograph of Moran, although I am
pretty sure I have one somewhere. I am sending you to read his letter to me.
Please return it when you are through with it. The letter gives his present
address.

You ask whether I think you are stressing Kissinger too much. I
have no criticism to make of your fine and generous enthusiasm for Kissinger,
and prefer to say you have stressed Moran too little. He was without doubt
the finest and strongest character of the group of men infected at Camp Lazear,
and my recollection is that he and Kissinger volunteered at the same time.
They were the first to be bitten by mosquitoes that were infected, but for
some reason Moran was not infected, when bitten on November 26th (1900) or
November 29th by mosquitoes brought to him in test tubes and placed on his
arm. He was the first one to be infected by mosquitoes in the natural way
when they were liberated in a room in a little house on the left hand side
of the photograph #40731 and he came down on Christmas Day, 1900. You re-
member Reed made a very dramatic illustration of what was meant by an infected
(Cont. on reverse side)
Ac
M
(continued from reverse side)
room by dividing this building into two rooms by a mosquito wire part-
ition only; on one side of the wire partitions non-immunes slept safely,
while the men who went into the other side in which there were infected
mosquitoes came down with the fever.

Very sincerely yours,
J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U. S. Army, Retired.
